topics.title: Python Strings
topics.description: Master string operations, formatting, methods, and string manipulation in Python

contents.title: Introduction to Strings
contents.content:
Strings are sequences of characters used to store text. In Python, strings are immutable (cannot be changed after creation).

String Features:
‚Ä¢ Enclosed in quotes (single, double, or triple)
‚Ä¢ Immutable (cannot modify existing string)
‚Ä¢ Indexed (access characters by position)
‚Ä¢ Iterable (can loop through characters)
‚Ä¢ Support many built-in methods

Creating Strings:
‚Ä¢ Single quotes: 'Hello'
‚Ä¢ Double quotes: "Hello"
‚Ä¢ Triple quotes: '''Hello''' or """Hello"""
‚Ä¢ Triple quotes for multi-line strings

String Characteristics:
‚Ä¢ Zero-indexed (first character at index 0)
‚Ä¢ Support negative indexing (-1 for last)
‚Ä¢ Can be concatenated with +
‚Ä¢ Can be repeated with *
‚Ä¢ Support slicing [start:end]

Common Use Cases:
‚Ä¢ Store names, addresses, messages
‚Ä¢ Process text data
‚Ä¢ Format output
‚Ä¢ Parse user input
‚Ä¢ Work with files and APIs

contents.title: Creating and Accessing Strings
contents.content:
# Creating strings
name = 'Raj Sharma'
city = "Mumbai"
message = '''This is a
multi-line
string'''

print(name)     # Raj Sharma
print(city)     # Mumbai
print(message)  # Multi-line output

# Quotes inside strings
text1 = "He said, 'Hello!'"
text2 = 'She said, "Hi!"'
text3 = "She said, \"Hello!\""  # Escape quote

print(text1)
print(text2)
print(text3)

# String indexing (accessing characters)
text = 'Python'
print(text[0])   # P (first character)
print(text[1])   # y
print(text[5])   # n (last character)
# print(text[6])  # IndexError

# Negative indexing (from end)
print(text[-1])  # n (last)
print(text[-2])  # o (second last)
print(text[-6])  # P (first)

# String length
name = 'Priya'
print(len(name))  # 5

text = 'Hello World'
print(len(text))  # 11 (space counts!)

# String slicing [start:end:step]
text = 'Python Programming'

print(text[0:6])    # Python (0 to 5)
print(text[7:18])   # Programming
print(text[:6])     # Python (start to 5)
print(text[7:])     # Programming (7 to end)
print(text[:])      # Python Programming (full)

# Slicing with step
print(text[::2])    # Pto rgamn (every 2nd char)
print(text[::-1])   # gnimmargorP nohtyP (reverse)

# Negative slicing
print(text[-11:])   # Programming
print(text[:-12])   # Python

examples.title: String Concatenation and Repetition
examples.code:
# Concatenation with +
first_name = 'Raj'
last_name = 'Sharma'
full_name = first_name + ' ' + last_name
print(full_name)  # Raj Sharma

# Multiple concatenation
greeting = 'Hello' + ', ' + 'World' + '!'
print(greeting)  # Hello, World!

# Concatenation with numbers (need conversion)
age = 25
# message = 'Age: ' + age  # TypeError
message = 'Age: ' + str(age)  # Convert to string
print(message)  # Age: 25

# String repetition with *
line = '-' * 20
print(line)  # --------------------

pattern = 'Ha' * 3
print(pattern)  # HaHaHa

spaces = ' ' * 5
print('Hello' + spaces + 'World')  # Hello     World

# Practical examples
print('=' * 30)
print('Welcome to Python')
print('=' * 30)

# Create separator
print('\n' + '-' * 40 + '\n')

# Repeat pattern
stars = '*' * 10
print(stars)
print('  Title  ')
print(stars)
examples.explanation: Use + to join strings and * to repeat strings. Remember to convert numbers to strings before concatenation.
